text: 4.614 is a course that

I meant to have it as an
introduction to Islamic

cultures, and I am using it in a
plural in here,

through looking at one specific
kind of architecture which,

of course, would be the most
related to what we would call

Islamic culture,
which is the religious

architecture of those cultures.
And I am using it in the plural

because I do not want to convey
the image that what we are

looking at is a monolithic
culture from beginning to end

and it is the same in every
place that professes Islam as a

religion or that accepts Islam
as a religion.

So it is really a survey course
that tries to use architecture,

and a specific kind of
architecture,

in order to introduce to the
undergraduate and to the

uninitiated the idea of what
makes a society or a culture an

Islamic society or an Islamic
culture through their religious

practices within religious
spaces and through their tastes

and their favorite forms and
decorative patterns and so on in

these religious spaces.
And what is the symbolic

meaning and perhaps actually
most of the religious meaning of

these spaces and these
decorative patterns,

these structural solutions.
Where are the influences coming

from?
How did this these cultures

interact with each other or with
cultures that are external to

the Islamic world?
How did these affect the

development of the Islamic
architecture of these cultures,

and how, vice versa,
sometimes they affected the

cultures outside?
The structure of 4.614 and the

way it has developed over the
years, although actually from

the beginning I wanted it to be
that way, there is a history and

the history of architecture
class.

A typical session would start
with me setting the tone for the

period that we are in.
So I would tell them about the

major events of that period,
who was doing what in terms of

the important people because,
of course, actually for

pre-modern history we know more
about the rulers than we know

about the rule.
So there is an introduction of

which dynasty is ruling,
where did they come from,

what kind of culture they came
from, what kind of idea and

ideals they were looking for.
And then we start introducing

the monuments.
And the monuments are

introduced in relationship to
their historic context and also

in relationship to the continuum
that is Islamic architecture.

That is in every session I try
to relate what they are looking

at to something that they have
either looked at before or

something that I assume,
and sometimes I assume

mistakenly, that they know
about.

4.614 is actually marked as a
HASD class here at MIT which is,

in a sense, a core curriculum
in the humanities that is

available for all the
undergraduate students to take

as a fulfillment of their
humanities requirement.

So it comes with a set of rules
with it about how you expect

students to progress in a class.
And students are expected to

produce between 20 and 25 pages
of writing that are divided

among four or five exercises.
And they are supposed to take

part in discussions related to
specific topics within the

class.
And, at the end of the class,

there is an exam.
These are the three methods of

evaluation.
And the other aspect that I use

in the evaluation is actually my
exams are usually designed so

that they are not a reflection
of how much material the

students have managed to
memorize but how much ideas they

have managed to internalize.
The other thing that I try to

do is actually,
although it is a historic

class, and I do want it to
remain fully ensconced within

the history of Islamic religion
and cultures,

I try to bring in current
affairs into the class where I

bring in parallels by drawing
the student's attention.

For example,
now in Iraq,

people are getting used to the
names of the Iraqi cities.

And we look at a few monuments
in there, so I immediately make

the contact in there and make
the connection between what is

happening in those cities today
the students have heard about

and what happened,
say, in the 7th or 8th century

in the same city.
4.614 is a course that is part

of the courses that are
sponsored and introduced into

the Department of Architecture
by the Aga Khan Program for

Islamic Architecture.
Which is a program endowed by

the Aga Khan in 1979 to
basically promote and support

the teaching and research on
Islamic architecture within the

Department of Architecture.
4.614, in particular,

is a rather successful class
because it is a survey class,

because it introduces a whole
tradition from beginning to end.

And because,
as opposed to the usual class

of survey of Islamic
architecture in departments of

art history, they usually stop
with the last wave of grand

monuments of Islamic tradition.
I would say,

for example,
the 17th century Mughal

architecture of India is where
they stopped because what

happened after is usually
considered to be something that

is much more influenced by the
development in the West,

especially in Europe.
But I stopped,

actually, with mosques that
were built two years ago,

three years ago,
stuff like that.

And I relate them to the first
mosque that is now 1,500 years

old.
So I actually create a living

tradition in the mind of the
student.

And, in a sense,
this is the mark of the success

of the class.
One thing that I learned from

having taught this course for
all these years,

and actually that is reflected
in the way the course has been

introduced on OCW,
is less is better.

Initially, of course,
when I started teaching the

course, I wanted to show as many
buildings as possible.

I wanted to touch upon as many
areas as possible.

Ultimately, I realized that if
I can actually spend half an

hour speaking about a small
building and trying to show the

students the intricacy of its
architecture and its decoration

and try to connect its very
specific context,

like what happened in the year
of its building and stuff like

that, the students will have a
much better appreciation of the

architecture than if you showed
them ten buildings each with

like ten slides and say,
look, we covered now the

Umayyad periods,
for example.

The students will come out of
the class and say we have no

idea what he was talking about.
I am showing you how it is

better to appreciate looking at
buildings, understanding

buildings within their context,
relating them to their history,

seeing them as a product of
their history,

but I don't want you to
actually come out of the class

and sort of like say the Umayyad
period, one, two,

three, four,
five, six, seven,

eight, nine,
ten, these are the most famous

buildings.
This is not a Jeopardy program.

It is actually a learning
experience.
